prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Lost credit card replaced with new card and new numbers. Credit score affected?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, replacing a lost credit card can have an impact on your credit score. When you report a lost or stolen credit card to your issuer, they will typically put a "fraud alert" on your account, which can affect your credit score. This alert indicates to lenders that your card has been lost or stolen, and they may view you as a higher credit risk.

Additionally, when you receive a replacement card with new numbers, this can also cause a temporary drop in your credit score. This is because the new card numbers may not be linked to your old account history, which can affect the calculation of your credit score.

However, the impact on your credit score will be temporary, and your score should recover within a few months as your new account history and payment history are reported to the credit bureaus. It's important to make sure that you continue to make timely payments and manage your credit responsibly to help your credit score recover as quickly as possible.

It's worth noting that the extent of the impact on your credit score will depend on the specific circumstances of your situation. For example, if you have a long history of responsible credit use and have recently had a card replaced due to loss or theft, the impact on your score may be less significant. On the other hand, if you have a history of late payments or credit mistakes, the impact on your score may be more significant.
answers: The true answer is it depends because  it is up to the credit card issuer to follow the right path when issuing a replacement credit card. http://www.bankrate.com/finance/credit-cards/will-replacement-card-hurt-my-score.aspx Typically, issuers will transfer the account history to the new trade line, says Barry Paperno, the consumer operations manager at FICO, the creator of the FICO scoring formula. The new account should have the old open date, so you should retain your payment history, he says. The credit limit and balance should also stay the same. http://blog.credit.com/2014/02/lost-or-stolen-credit-card-hurt-your-credit-scores-76724/ How Issuers Report Replacement Cards We asked the major card issuers how they report replacement cards to credit reporting agencies: American Express: The new card has the same open date and “Member Since” year as the previous card. The balance on the old account number is transferred to the new account number. All payment history transfers over. Bank of America: All transactions and account history are transferred to the new account number when there is a card replacement or renewal. Capital One: The new account number with all the original account data (original open date, etc.) is reported along with a notification to the bureaus that the new account number is replacing the old.  The two tradelines can then be ‘merged’ into one, so that all the applicable payment history, balance, etc. is now under the new account number. Chase: The original tradeline does not change. The history on the account remains, just the account number field is updated with the new account number. There is no “new” tradeline in this scenario.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Do dividend quotes for U.S. stocks include witheld taxes?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I'm glad to help! Dividend quotes for U.S. stocks typically do not include withheld taxes. When a company declares a dividend, the dividend quote will show the amount of the dividend per share, but it will not include any taxes that may be withheld by the company on behalf of the shareholder.

In the United States, dividends are considered taxable income, and shareholders are responsible for reporting and paying any taxes due on their dividend income. The amount of taxes owed will depend on the shareholder's individual tax situation and may include federal and state taxes.

It's worth noting that some companies may withhold taxes on dividends paid to non-U.S. investors. This is known as "withholding tax" and is typically a percentage of the dividend amount. The withheld tax amount will be deducted from the dividend payment before it is deposited into the investor's account.

Overall, when looking at dividend quotes for U.S. stocks, it's important to keep in mind that the quoted dividend amount does not include any taxes that may be withheld. Shareholders should consult with their tax advisor or financial professional to determine their tax obligations and to ensure they are properly reporting their dividend
answers: The dividend quoted on a site like the one you linked to on Yahoo shows what 1 investor owning 1 share received from the company. It is not adjusted at all for taxes. (Actually some dividend quotes are adjusted but not for taxes... see below.)  It is not adjusted because most dividends are taxed as ordinary income. This means different rates for different people, and so for simplicity's sake the quotes just show what an investor would be paid.  You're responsible for calculating and paying your own taxes.  From the IRS website: Ordinary Dividends Ordinary (taxable) dividends are the most common type of distribution from a corporation or a mutual fund. They are paid out of earnings and profits and are ordinary income to you. This means they are not capital gains. You can assume that any dividend you receive on common or preferred stock is an ordinary dividend unless the paying corporation or mutual fund tells you otherwise. Ordinary dividends will be shown in box 1a of the Form 1099-DIV you receive. Now my disclaimer... what you see on a normal stock quote for dividend in Yahoo or Google Finance is adjusted. (Like here for GE.) Many corporations actually pay out quarterly dividends. So the number shown for a dividend will be the most recent quarterly dividend [times] 4 quarters. To find out what you would receive as an actual payment, you would need to divide GE's current $0.76 dividend by 4 quarters... $0.19. So you would receive that amount for each share of stock you owned in GE.

To stop an ACH transaction, you can contact your bank and request that they reverse the transaction. The bank will then notify the originating bank, which will stop the transfer of funds. Additionally, if the originating bank has already settled the funds and transferred them to the recipient's account, the reversal may not be possible, and you may need to contact the recipient to request that they return the funds.

It's also worth noting that NACHA rules require that banks have a process in place for handling ACH reversals, and that the reversal process must be completed within a certain timeframe to avoid additional fees or penalties.

In summary, while it is possible to block previously

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Does the low CAD positively or negatively impact Canadian Investors?[/INST]
pred:
A low Canadian Alternative to the US dollar (CAD) can have both positive and negative impacts on Canadian investors.

Positive impacts:

1. Export competitiveness: A low CAD can make Canadian exports more competitive in the global market, leading to increased demand and higher revenues for businesses. This can have a positive impact on the overall economy and create jobs.
2. Foreign investment: A low CAD can make Canada more attractive to foreign investors, as they can buy assets denominated in Canadian dollars at a discount compared to the US dollar. This can lead to increased foreign investment and higher demand for Canadian assets such as stocks, bonds, and real estate.
3. Tourism: A low CAD can make travel to Canada more affordable for foreign tourists, leading to increased tourism and related industries such as hospitality and transportation.

Negative impacts:

1. Import costs: A low CAD can make imports cheaper, which can lead to increased costs for businesses and consumers. This can negatively impact the overall economy and lead to higher inflation.
2. Interest rates: A low CAD can lead to higher interest rates, as investors demand higher yields to compensate for the lower currency value. This can negatively impact borrowers, particularly those with variable-rate mortgages or other
answers: When you want to invest in an asset denominated by a foreign currency, your investment is going to have some currency risk to it. You need to worry not just about what happens to your own currency, but also the foreign currency. Lets say you want to invest $10000 in US Stocks as a Canadian. Today that will cost you $13252, since USDCAD just hit 1.3252. You now have two ways you can make money. One is if USDCAD goes up, two is if the stocks go up. The former may not be obvious, but remember, you are holding US denominated assets currently, with the intention of one day converting those assets back into CAD. Essentially, you are long USDCAD (long USD short CAD). Since you are short CAD, if CAD goes up it hurts you It may seem odd to think about this as a currency trade, but it opens up a possibility. If you want a foreign investment to be currency neutral, you just make the opposite currency trade, in addition to your original investment. So in this case, you would buy $10,000 in US stocks, and then short USDCAD (ie long CAD, short USD $10,000). This is kind of savvy and may not be something you would do. But its worth mentioning. And there are also some currency hedged ETFs out there that do this for you http://www.ishares.com/us/strategies/hedge-currency-impact However most are hedged relative to USD, and are meant to hedge the target countries currency, not your own.

Using stop-loss as risk management: Is it safe?[/INST]
pred:
As a helpful assistant, I'm glad to help you understand the concept of stop-loss orders in risk management.

A stop-loss order is an investment strategy used to limit potential losses by automatically selling a security when its price falls below a predetermined level. The stop-loss order is designed to help investors manage risk by limiting their potential losses to a specific amount.

Is it safe to use stop-loss orders for risk management? The answer is complex and depends on various factors. Here are some points to consider:

1. Protection against large losses: Stop-loss orders can provide protection against large losses by limiting the amount of money that can be lost in a single trade. This can be especially important for investors who are new to the market or who have a limited investment portfolio.
2. Flexibility: Stop-loss orders can be adjusted as market conditions change, allowing investors to adapt their risk management strategies accordingly.
3. Risk of slippage: While stop-loss orders can help protect against large losses, there is a risk of slippage, which occurs when the security's price falls below the stop-loss price before the order is executed. This can result in larger losses than anticipated.
4. Whipsaw effect: The stop-loss order can lead to the whipsaw effect, where the security's price fluct
answers: A stop-loss order becomes a market order when a trade has occurred at or below the trigger price you set when creating the order. This means that you could possibly end up selling some or all of your position at a price lower than your trigger price. For relatively illiquid securities your order may be split into transactions with several buyers at different prices and you could see a significant drop in price between the first part of the order and the last few shares. To mitigate this, brokers also offer a stop-limit order, where you set not only a trigger price, but also a minimum price that you are will to accept for your shares. This reduces the risk of selling at rock bottom prices, especially if you are selling a very large position. However, in the case of a flash crash where other sellers are driving the price below your limit, that part of your order may never execute and you could end up being stuck with a whole lot of shares that are worth less than both your stop loss trigger and limit price. For securities that are liquid and not very volatile, either option is a pretty safe way to cut your losses. For securities that are illiquid and/or very volatile a stop-limit order will prevent you from cashing out at bottom dollar and giving away a bargain to lurkers hanging out at the bottom of the market, but you may end up stuck with shares you don't want for longer than originally planned. It's up to you to decide which kind of risk you prefer.

answers: Capital losses do mirror capital gains within their holding periods. An asset or investment this is certainly held for a year into the day or less, and sold at a loss, will create a short-term capital loss. A sale of any asset held for over a year to your day, and sold at a loss, will create a loss that is long-term. When capital gains and losses are reported from the tax return, the taxpayer must first categorize all gains and losses between long and short term, and then aggregate the sum total amounts for every single regarding the four categories. Then the gains that are long-term losses are netted against each other, therefore the same is done for short-term gains and losses. Then your net gain that is long-term loss is netted against the net short-term gain or loss. This final net number is then reported on Form 1040. Example Frank has the following gains and losses from his stock trading for the year: Short-term gains - $6,000 Long-term gains - $4,000 Short-term losses - $2,000 Long-term losses - $5,000 Net short-term gain/loss - $4,000 ST gain ($6,000 ST gain - $2,000 ST loss) Net long-term gain/loss - $1,000 LT loss ($4,000 LT gain - $5,000 LT loss) Final net gain/loss - $3,000 short-term gain ($4,000 ST gain - $1,000 LT loss)   Again, Frank can only deduct $3,000 of final net short- or long-term losses against other types of income for that year and must carry forward any remaining balance.

answers: According to the Fair Credit Reporting Act: any consumer reporting agency may furnish a consumer report [...] to a person which it has reason to believe [...] intends to use the information in connection with a credit transaction involving the consumer on whom the information is to be furnished and   involving the extension of credit to, or review or collection of an account of, the consumer See p12 (section 604). The usual interpretation of this that I've heard is that a debt collection agency that owns or has been assigned a debt can make hard pulls on your credit report without your consent. What is the difference between a stop order and a stop limit order?[/INST]
pred:
Great question! Both stop orders and stop limit orders are popular order types used by traders to control their trading risks, but they have some key differences:

Stop Order:
A stop order is an order to buy or sell a security when the price reaches a certain level (known as the stop price). When the stop price is triggered, the stop order becomes a market order, which means it will be executed at the current market price. The main advantage of stop orders is that they provide flexibility and allow traders to enter the market at a desired price without having to continuously monitor the price.

Stop Limit Order:
A stop limit order, on the other hand, is an order to buy or sell a security when the price reaches a certain level (known as the stop price), but only at a specific price (known as the limit price). When the stop price is triggered, the stop limit order becomes a limit order, which means it will be executed at the limit price or better. The main advantage of stop limit orders is that they provide more control over the execution price, as they ensure that the order is executed at a specific price or better, rather than at the current market price.

Key Differences:

1. Execution Price: The main difference between stop orders and stop limit orders is the execution price. Stop orders are executed at the current market price when the stop price is triggered, while stop limit orders
answers: An attempt at a simple answer for the normal investor: A normal investor buys stock then later sells that stock. (This is known as "going long", as opposed to "going short").  For the normal investor, a stop order (of either kind) is only used when selling. A stop-loss sell order (or stop sell) is used to sell your stock when it has fallen too much in price, and you don't want to suffer more losses.  If the stock is at $50, you could enter a stop sell at $40, which means if the stock ever falls to $40 or lower, your stock will be sold at whatever price is available (e.g. $35). A stop-loss limit sell order (or stop limit sell) is the same, except you are also saying "but don't sell for less than my limit price".  So you can enter a stop limit sell at $40 with a limit of $39, meaning that if the stock falls to $40, you will then have a limit order in effect to sell the stock at $39 or higher.  Thus your stock will never be sold at $35 or any value below $39, but of course, if the stock falls fast from $40 to $35, your limit sell at $39 will not be done and you will be left still owning the stock (worth at that moment $35, say).

Related hedges are financial instruments used to manage risk associated with specific assets or liabilities. They are designed to mitigate the impact of price movements in the underlying asset or liability on the overall financial position of an investor or company. Here's how they work:

1. Definition: A related hedge is a financial instrument that is used to offset the risk of price movements in an underlying asset or liability. This can include interest rate swaps, forward contracts, options, and futures contracts.
2. Examples: Some common examples of related hedges include interest rate swaps, which can be used to manage exposure to changes in interest rates; forward contracts, which can be used to lock in prices for a future transaction; and options, which can provide the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell an underlying asset at a specified price on or before a certain date.
3. How they work: Related hedges work by creating a opposite exposure to the underlying asset or liability. For example, if an investor owns a bond with a fixed coupon rate, they may enter into an interest rate swap to receive a floating interest rate in exchange for the fixed coupon payments. This creates a hedge against changes in interest rates, as the floating interest rate will offset the changes in the bond's value.
4. Advantages: Related h
answers: In this type of strategy profit is made when the shares go down as your main position is the short trade of the common stock. Yes, there is a converse to dollar-cost-averaging, which is called "lump-sum investing" or "one-time investment." Dollar-cost-averaging involves investing a fixed amount of money at regular intervals, regardless of the market's performance. Lump-sum investing, on the other hand, involves investing a single amount of money at one time, without any regular interval.

Lump-sum investing can be a low-risk strategy when done strategically. The idea behind it is that the market may be undervalued at a particular point in time, and by investing a large sum of money at that point, you can potentially benefit from the market's eventual increase in value. This strategy can be especially beneficial for investors who have a long-term investment horizon and are willing to take on some level of market risk.

There are a few key factors to consider when using a lump-sum investment strategy:

1. Time horizon: Lump-sum investing is best suited for investors with a long-term investment horizon, as it can take several years for the market to recover from any potential downturns.
2. Risk tolerance: Lump-sum investing involves taking on market risk, which can be higher than the risk associated with dollar-cost-averaging. Invest

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

“Convertible -debt/note/bond/debentures” which of these are the same or different?[/INST]
pred:
Convertible debt, notes, bonds, and debentures are all financial instruments that are similar in some ways but also have some key differences.

Convertible debt is a type of debt instrument that can be converted into equity shares of the issuing company at a later date. This means that the holder of the convertible debt has the option to convert their debt into ownership in the company, usually under certain conditions. Convertible debt is often used by companies as a way to attract investors when they do not have access to the capital markets, or when they want to keep their costs low.

Notes, on the other hand, are a type of debt instrument that has a fixed interest rate and a maturity date. They are similar to bonds but are typically unsecured and have a shorter maturity date. Notes are often used by companies to borrow money for a short period of time, usually less than a year.

Bonds are a type of debt instrument that has a fixed interest rate and a maturity date. They are similar to notes but are typically secured by assets of the issuing company and have a longer maturity date. Bonds are often used by companies to borrow money for a long period of time, usually several years or more.

Debentures are a type of long-term debt instrument that is not secured by any assets of the
answers: They all basically mean the same thing - a type of debt than can be exchanged for (converted into) equity at some point. It's only the mechanics that can be different. A convertible bond is structured just like a regular bond - it (usually) pays periodic interest and has a face value that's due at maturity. The difference is that the bond holder has the option to exchange the debt for equity at some point during the life of the bond.  There can be restrictions on when that conversion is possible, and they typically define a quantity of equity (number of shares) that the bond can be converted into.  If the market price of the shares goes above a price that would make the shares more valuable than the bond, it's in the best interest of the bond holder to convert. A convertible note is typically used to describe a kind of startup financing that does not pay interest or have a face value that's redeemed, but instead is redeemed for equity as part of a later financing round.  Rather than specifying a specific number of shares, the bond holder receives equity at a certain discount to the rest of the market. So they both are debt instruments that can turn into equity investments, just through different mechanisms. A debenture is a fancy word for unsecured debt, and convertible debt could be used to described either structure above, so those terms could mean either type of structure.

answers: There is certainly an obligation in some cases of a company to distribute profit, either as dividend or a stock buy back. Activist investors frequently push for one or the other when a company is doing well - sometimes to the detriment of future growth, in some eyes - and can even file shareholder lawsuits (saying the company is not doing its duty to its shareholders by simply holding onto cash).  Apple famously held out from doing either for years under Steve Jobs, and only in the last few years started doing both - a large dividend and a share buy-back which increases the value of remaining shares (as EPS then goes up with fewer shares out there).  Carl Icahn for example is one of those investors in Apple's case [and in many cases!] who put significant pressure, particularly when they were sitting on hundreds of billions of dollars. Ultimately, a (for-profit) corporation's board is tasked with maximizing its shareholder's wealth; as such, it can buy back shares, pay dividends, sell the company, liquidate the company, or expand the company, at its discretion, so long as it can justify to its shareholders that it is still attempting to maximize the value of their holdings.  Companies in their growth phase often don't return any money and simply reinvest - but the long-term hope is to either return money in the form of dividends on profits, or the sale of the company.

answers: A huge amount of money in all financial markets is from institutional investors, such as mutual funds, government pension plans, sovereign wealth funds, etc.  For various reasons these funds do all of their trading at the end of the day.  They care primarily that their end-of-day balances are in line with their targets and are easy to audit and far less about "timing the market" for the best possible trades. So, if you're looking at a stock that is owned by many institutional investors -- such as a stock (like AAPL) that makes up a significant portion of an index that many funds track -- there will be a huge amount of activity at this time relative to stocks that are less popular among institutions. Even just in its introduction this paper (PDF) gives a fair overview of other reasons why there's a lot of trading at end-of-day in general. (In fact, because of all this closing activity and the reliance on end-of-day prices as signposts for financial calculations, the end-of-day has for decades been the single most fraud-ridden time of the trading day.  Electronic trading has done away with a lot of the straight-up thievery that floor traders and brokers used to get away with at the expense of the public, but it still exists.  See, for example, any explanation of the term banging the close, or the penalties against 6 banks just last month for manipulating the FX market at the close.)

prompt:

Can an ETF perform differently than its holdings?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, an exchange-traded fund (ETF) can perform differently than its holdings in several ways. Here are some reasons why:

1. Rebalancing: ETFs are required to rebalance their portfolios periodically to maintain their target weights. This means that the ETF may sell some of its holdings to buy more of others, even if their prices have changed. This can lead to the ETF outperforming or underperforming its holdings, depending on the market conditions.
2. Index construction: The performance of an ETF can be influenced by the methodology used to construct the underlying index. For example, some indexes may weight holdings by market capitalization, while others may use a different weighting scheme. This can lead to differences in performance between the ETF and its holdings, even if they are identical.
3. Fees and expenses: ETFs have operating expenses, such as management fees and trading costs, which can erode performance over time. These fees and expenses can be higher or lower than those of the underlying holdings, leading to differences in performance.
4. Trading activity: ETFs are traded on stock exchanges, and their prices can fluctuate based on market demand. This can lead to differences between the ETF's Net Asset Value (NAV) and its market price, which can affect performance.
answers: The Creation/Redemption mechanism is how shares of an ETF are created or redeemed as needed and thus is where there can be differences in what the value of the holdings can be versus the trading price. If the ETF is thinly traded, then the difference could be big as more volume would be where the mechanism could kick in as generally there are blocks required so the mechanism usually created or redeemed in lots of 50,000 shares I believe. From the link where AP=Authorized Participant: With ETFs, APs do most of the buying and selling. When APs sense   demand for additional shares of an ETF—which manifests itself when the   ETF share price trades at a premium to its NAV—they go into the market   and create new shares. When the APs sense demand from investors   looking to redeem—which manifests itself when the ETF share price   trades at a discount—they process redemptions. So, suppose the NAV of the ETF is $20/share and the trading price is $30/share. The AP can buy the underlying securities for $20/share in a bulk order that equates to 50,000 shares of the ETF and exchange the underlying shares for new shares in the ETF. Then the AP can turn around and sell those new ETF shares for $30/share and pocket the gain. If you switch the prices around, the AP would then take the ETF shares and exchange them for the underlying securities in the same way and make a profit on the difference. SEC also notes this same process.

As mhoran_psprep said, some of it goes to pay interest to the depositors; some of it goes to pay the bank's expenses like employee salaries, cost of the building, etc; and some of it goes as profit to the owners or stockholders of the bank. If you're thinking, "Wow, I'm paying back a whole lot more than I borrowed", well, yes. But remember you're borrowing that money for 20 or 30 years. The bank isn't making very much money on the loan each year that you have it -- these days something like 4 or 5% in the U.S., I don't know what the going rates are in other countries.

UK Gilts are a type of government bond issued by the UK government to borrow money from investors. The interest rates and repayments on Gilts work as follows:

Gilt interest rates are determined by the market forces of supply and demand. The yield on a Gilt is the return an investor can expect to receive for investing in the bond, and it is calculated as a percentage of the bond's face value. The yield is made up of two components: the nominal interest rate, which is the rate at which the bond is issued, and the real interest rate, which reflects the rate of inflation.

For example, if the nominal interest rate on a Gilt is 2%, and inflation is 3%, the real interest rate is 1%. This means that for every £100 invested in the bond, the investor will receive £2 in interest over the course of a year, but the purchasing power of that £2 will be reduced by 3% due to inflation.

Repayment:
Gilts are repaid to investors when they mature, which can range from 5 to 40 years. The repayment amount is the face value of the bond, which is the amount borrowed by the government. For example, if an investor
answers: The name of the Gilt states the redemption date, but not the original issue date. A gilt with 8.75% yield and close to its redemption date may have been issued at a time when interest rates were indeed close to 8.75%. For example in the early 1990s, the UK inflation rate was about 8%. One reason for preferring high or low coupon gilts is the trade off between capital gains and income, and the different taxation rules for each. If you buy a gilt and hold it to its maturity date, you know in advance the exact price that it will be redeemed for (i.e. £100). You may prefer to take a high level of income now, knowing you will make a capital loss in future (which might offset some other predictable capital gain for tax purposes) or you may prefer not to take income that you don't need right now, and instead get a guaranteed capital gain in future (for example, when you plan to retire from work). Also, you can use the change in the market value of gilts as a gamble or a hedge against your expectation of interest rate changes in future, with the "government guaranteed" fallback position that if your predictions are wrong, you know exactly what return you will get if you hold the gilts to maturity. The same idea applies to other bond investments - but without the government guarantee, of course.

Gift-giving during the holiday season is a common practice, but when does a gift "count" for tax purposes? In general, gifts are considered taxable income for the recipient if they are considered "gifts" under the Internal Revenue Code (IRC).

According to the IRC, a gift is any transfer to an individual without adequate consideration, such as money, goods, or services. The value of the gift is generally the fair market value of the item or service transferred.

For tax purposes, gifts are considered taxable income for the recipient if they meet certain thresholds. For cash gifts, the recipient must receive more than $15,000 in a calendar year without reporting the gift on their tax return. Any amount below $15,000 is not subject to tax reporting.

For non-cash gifts, such as clothing, household items, or other tangible personal property, the recipient must report the fair market value of the gift on their tax return if it exceeds $250. Gifts that are in excess of $5,000 to a single recipient (or $10,000 to a cumulative total of recipients) are considered "deemed gifts" and may be subject to gift tax.

It's worth noting that there are some

The expense ratio is expressed as a percentage of the fund's assets and is usually deducted directly from the fund's returns.

To quantify the differences in return between low expense ratio and high expense ratio mutual funds, you can use the following formula:

Return = (Total Assets - Expense Ratio) / Total Assets

For example, if you have a mutual fund with $10 million in assets and an expense ratio of 1%, the annual fee would be $100,000 (1% of $10 million). The return on the investment would be:

Return = ($10 million - $100,000) / $10 million = 9%

Now, let's compare this to a high expense ratio mutual fund with an expense ratio of 2%. The annual fee would be $200,000 (2% of $10 million), resulting in a lower return of:

Return = ($10 million - $200,000) / $10 million = 7.6%

Investing in dividend-yielding stocks with money borrowed from margin account?[/INST]

Investing in dividend-yielding stocks with money borrowed from a margin account can be a lucrative strategy for investors seeking to generate passive income. Margin accounts allow investors to borrow money from a broker to buy more stocks than they could otherwise afford, potentially increasing their returns. However, it's essential to understand the risks involved and to carefully consider the potential consequences of using margin to invest in dividend-yielding stocks.

Here are some key points to keep in mind:

1. Leverage: By using margin to invest in dividend-yielding stocks, investors can potentially increase their returns by borrowing money at a lower interest rate than the dividend yield. However, this leverage can also amplify losses if the stock price declines.
2. Interest costs: Investors must pay interest on the borrowed funds, which can eat into their returns. The interest costs will be higher if the stock price declines, which can further reduce the investor's returns.
3. Margin calls: If the value of the portfolio falls below a certain threshold, the broker may issue a margin call, requiring the investor to deposit more money or sell some of their holdings to cover the borrowed funds. This can be a significant risk, as investors may not be able to meet the margin call or may not want to sell
answers: In addition to the other answers, here's a proper strategy that implements your idea: If the options are priced properly they should account for future dividend payments, so all other things aside, a put option that is currently at the money should be in the money after the dividend, and hence more expensive than a put option that is out of the money today but at the money after the dividend has been paid. The unprotected futures (if priced correctly) should account for dividend payments based on the dividend history and, since maturing after the payment, should earn you (you sell them) less money because you deliver the physical after the dividend has been paid. The protected ones should reflect the expected total return value of the stock at the time of maturity (i.e. the dividend is mentally calculated into the price), and any dividend payments that happen on the way will be debited from your cash (and credited to the counterparty). Now that's the strategy that leaves you with nearly no risk (the only risk you bear is that the dividend isn't as high as you expected).  But for that comfort you have to pay premiums.  So to see if you're smarter than the market, subtract all the costs for the hedging instruments from your envisaged dividend yield and see if your still better than the lending rate.  If so, do the trade.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are wash sale rules different for stocks and ETFs / Mutual Funds?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, wash sale rules are different for stocks, ETFs/mutual funds, and other securities. The wash sale rule is a tax provision in the US Tax Code that aims to prevent investors from claiming a loss on the sale of a security if they purchase a substantially identical security within 30 days before or after the sale.

For stocks, the wash sale rule applies when an investor sells a stock at a loss and then repurchases the same or substantially identical stock within 30 days. In this case, the loss is disallowed, and the investor is treated as having sold the new shares at the higher cost basis of the previously sold shares. This prevents investors from claiming a tax deduction for a loss on a stock sale if they Plan to repurchase the same stock in the near future.

ETFs/mutual funds are treated differently under the wash sale rule. When an investor sells a shares of an ETF or mutual fund, the wash sale rule does not apply to the underlying securities. Instead, the investor is treated as having sold the shares at the net asset value (NAV) of the fund on the date of the sale. This means that the investor can still claim a loss on the sale of the shares, even if they purchase a substantially identical ETF or mutual fund within
answers: The IRS rules are actually the same.  26 U.S. Code § 1091 - Loss from wash sales of stock or securities In   the case of any loss claimed to have been sustained from any sale or   other disposition of shares of stock or securities where it appears   that, within a period beginning 30 days before the date of such sale   or disposition and ending 30 days after such date, the taxpayer has   acquired (by purchase or by an exchange on which the entire amount of   gain or loss was recognized by law), or has entered into a contract or   option so to acquire, substantially identical stock or securities,   then no deduction shall be allowed... What you should take away from the quote above is "substantially identical stock or securities." With stocks, one company may happen to have a high correlation, Exxon and Mobil come to mind, before their merger of course. With funds or ETFs, the story is different. The IRS has yet to issue rules regarding what level of overlap or correlation makes two funds or ETFs "substantially identical."  Last month, I wrote an article, Tax Loss Harvesting, which analyses the impact of taking losses each year. I study the 2000's which showed an average loss of 1% per year, a 9% loss for the decade. Tax loss harvesting made the decade slightly positive, i.e. an annual boost of approx 1%.

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

Are capitalization rate and net profit margin the same thing?[/INST]
pred:
No, capitalization rate and net profit margin are not the same thing, although they are both important metrics used in real estate investment analysis.

Capitalization rate, or cap rate, is the rate of return on a real estate investment property based on the property's net operating income (NOI) and its purchase price. The cap rate is calculated by dividing the NOI by the property's purchase price and is expressed as a percentage. For example, if a property has an NOI of $100,000 and was purchased for $1,000,000, the cap rate would be 10%. The cap rate is used to compare the potential return on investment between different properties and to determine the investment's overall profitability.

Net profit margin, on the other hand, is a financial metric that measures the amount of profit a business generates in relation to its revenue. It is calculated by dividing the business's net income by its revenue and is expressed as a percentage. The net profit margin provides insight into a business's overall profitability and can be used to compare the profitability of different businesses within the same industry.

While both capitalization rate and net profit margin are important metrics used in financial analysis, they are used to evaluate different aspects of an investment or business. The capitalization rate focuses on the potential return on investment
answers: Both of these terms do refer to your profit; they're just different ways of evaluating it. First, your definition of capitalization rate is flipped.  As explained here, it should be: On the other hand, as explained here: So cap rate is like a reverse unit cost approach to comparing two investments.  If house A costs $1M and you'll make $50K (profit) from it yearly, and house B costs $1.33M and you'll make $65K (profit) from it yearly, then you can compute cap rates to see that A is a more efficient investment from the point of view of income vs. amount-of-money-you-have-stuck-in-this-investment-and-unavailable-for-use-elsewhere. Profit margin, on the other hand, cares more about your ongoing expenses than about your total investment.  If it costs less to maintain property B than it does to maintain property A, then you could have something like: So B is a more efficient investment from the point of view of the fraction of your revenue you actually get to keep each year. Certainly you could think of the property's value as an opportunity cost and factor that into the net profit margin equation to get a more robust estimate of exactly how efficient your investment is.  You can keep piling more factors into the equation until you've accounted for every possible facet of your investment.  This is what accountants and economists spend their days doing. :-)

prompt:
[INST]You are a helpful assistant, please answer the following question with financial knowledge within 300 words:

How much is one “lot” of EUR/USD?[/INST]
pred:
Great, I'm glad to help!

In the foreign exchange market, a "lot" typically refers to a standardized amount of currency that is used to determine the price of a currency pair. The size of a lot can vary depending on the currency pair and the brokerage firm, but some common sizes for EUR/USD lots are:

* Mini lot: 10,000 units of the base currency (EUR or USD)
* Micro lot: 1,000 units of the base currency
* Standard lot: 100,000 units of the base currency

So, for example, if you are trading EUR/USD with a standard lot size of 100,000 units, and the exchange rate is 1.2000, then one "lot" of EUR/USD would be worth €120,000 (100,000 units x 1.2000).

It's worth noting that the lot size you choose will affect your trading costs, such as spreads and commissions, as well as your potential profit and loss. Larger lots typically have lower spreads and commissions, but also require more capital to trade.

I hope that helps! Let me know if you have any other questions.
answers: A lot (sometimes called a round lot) always refers to the quantity of physical good that you're getting, like a carton of eggs or a barrel of oil.  The tricky thing in the case of forex is that the physical good also happens to be a currency. A spot currency product trades in the denomination on the right-hand side (RHS) of the product name.  So if you're buying EUR/USD you are paying USD currency to get EUR "units", and if you're selling EUR/USD you are receiving USD by giving away EUR "units".  The EUR is the "physical good" in this case. The way I remember it is to think of all products (not just currencies) as trading pairs.  So AAPL in my mind is AAPL/USD.  When I buy AAPL/USD I am paying USD to get AAPL units.  When I sell AAPL/USD I am receiving USD by giving away AAPL units. The thing on the left is the physical good (even if it happens to be money) that you are exchanging, and the thing on the right is the money that you are exchanging. So, when I buy a lot of AAPL, I am buying 100 shares at their current price in dollars. Similarly, when I buy a lot of EUR/USD, I am buying 100K Euros at their current price in dollars.

Are RSUs ever taxed as long term capital gains?[/INST]
pred:
Restricted Stock Units (RSUs) are a form of equity compensation that companies use to reward their employees. RSUs are taxed differently than other forms of income, and whether they are taxed as long-term capital gains depends on several factors.

Generally, RSUs are taxed as ordinary income when they vest and are received by the employee. This means that the employee will pay taxes on the fair market value of the RSUs at the time of vesting, which can range from 20% to 37%, depending on the employee's tax bracket.

However, if an employee holds onto their RSUs for more than one year after vesting and sells them, the gain on the sale may be eligible for long-term capital gains treatment. This means that the employee may be taxed at a lower rate, ranging from 0% to 20%, depending on their tax bracket and the length of time the RSUs were held.

To qualify for long-term capital gains treatment, the RSUs must be held for more than one year after vesting. If the RSUs are sold before the one-year holding period, they will be taxed as ordinary income, and the employee will not be eligible for the lower capital gains tax rate.

As a helpful assistant, I'm glad to help you with your question! When one company takes over another, it's essential to understand how the transition will affect any outstanding balances.

In general, when one company takes over another, the new owner typically assumes responsibility for all outstanding debts and liabilities, including any unpaid balances on credit cards or loans. This means that you may not be required to pay the balance yourself.

However, there are some exceptions to this general rule. For example, if the acquisition is structured as a merger rather than an outright takeover, you may be required to pay the balance yourself. Over time, the returns can compound to generate a significant amount of money. For example, if you continued to reinvest the earnings each year for 20 years, you would have earned a total of $1,228.63 in interest, with a final balance of $222.86. There are different types of subsidies, including:

2. Indirect subsidies: These are benefits or privileges granted to an individual or organization that are not direct payments, but nevertheless provide financial support. 3. Trade subsidies: These are payments made to support a particular
answers: A subsidy is a payment made by a group (usually the state) to individuals or corporations in order to shift the balance if the rational economic decision for the individual would be detrimental to the group as a whole otherwise. For example, if there are different quality kinds of crops that can be planted, for example a GM maize that brings in high yields but can only be processed to High Fructose Corn Syrup or a naturally bred corn that brings lower yields but tastes well enough for direct consumption, then if demand for both exceeds supply, the economic choice for the individual farmer is to plant the former. If the claims that HFCS contribute to obesity are founded, then it is in the public interest to produce less of it, and more alternative foods. Given that a market rather than a planned economy is desired, this cannot be achieved by decree, but rather money is used as an incentive. In the long term, this investment may very well pay off through reduced health care costs, so it is a rational economic decision from the state's point of view. In a world where all actors make decisions that are fully in their self interest, in principle subsidies would not be needed as consumers would demand healthy rather than cheap foods, and market mechanisms would provide these.

As a helpful assistant, I'm glad to help you understand the concept of betting in casinos. When you place a bet in a casino, it is not a bet on price fluctuations, but rather a bet against the house edge.

In a casino, the house edge is the built-in advantage that the casino has over the player. This advantage is built into the odds of each game, and it ensures that the casino will make a profit in the long run. The house edge is calculated as a percentage, and it can range from as low as 1% to as high as 30% depending on the game.

For example, in a game like roulette, the house edge is approximately 5.26%. This means that for every $100 bet, the casino can expect to win $5.26 on average. The remaining $94.74 will go to the player, but over time, the casino will continue to make a profit due to the house edge.

In other words, when you place a bet in a casino, you are not betting on the price of the game to fluctuate. answers: The answer depends on the specific instrument to which you are referring. It is also possible to have such a contract be settled in the underlying (if the cash value is appropriate, then the cash settlement can be used to purchase the underlying directly, if necessary).  Physical delivery was predominant until the last few decades.  Most traders, as opposed to hedgers or strategics, are going to prefer cash-settled contracts as opposed to physical delivery. For example, if your Personal EBITDA is high, you may have more money available to save for retirement or pay off debt. answers: A lien is a mechanism to impede legal title transfer of a vehicle, real property, or sometimes, expensive business equipment.  That's why title companies exist - to make sure there are no liens against something before a buyer hands money to a seller. The lien can be attached to a loan, unpaid labor related to the item (a mechanic's lien) or unpaid taxes, and there are other scenarios where this could occur. The gist of all this is that the seller of the vehicle mentioned does not have clear title if there is a lien.  This introduces a risk for the buyer.  The buyer can pay the seller the money to cover the lien (in the case of a bank loan) but that doesn't mean the seller will actually pay off the loan (so the title is never clear!).  This article recommends visiting the bank with the seller, and getting title on-the-spot.  However, this isn't always an option, as a local bank branch isn't probably going to have the title document available, though the seller might be able to make some arrangement for a local branch to have the title available before a visit to pay off the loan. The low-risk approach is for the seller to have clear title before any money changes hands.

pred:
Short selling, also known as going short, is a financial strategy used by investors to profit from a decline in the price of a stock. In short selling, an investor borrows shares of a stock from a broker and sells them at the current market price. The investor then buys back the shares at a lower price, return them to the broker, and pocket the difference as profit.

To illustrate, let's say an investor believes that the price of XYZ stock is going to decline. They could short sell 100 shares of XYZ stock by borrowing those shares from a broker and selling them at the current market price of $50 per share. If the price of XYZ stock indeed declines to $40 per share, the investor can buy back the 100 shares at the lower price and return them to the broker. The investor would make a profit of $10 per share, or $1,000 on the 100 shares.

It's important to note that short selling is a high-risk strategy that can result in unlimited losses if the price of the stock rises instead of falls. This is because there is no upper limit to the price at which the stock can rise, and the investor is responsible for repaying the loan for the shares at the original
answers: The reason for selling a stock "short", is for when you believe the stock value will decrease in the near future. Here is an example: Today Exxon-Mobile stock is selling for $100 / share. You are expecting the price to decrease, so you want to short the stock, which means your broker (i.e. eTrade, etc) allows you to borrow shares without paying money, and those shares are transferred into your account, and then you sell them and receive money for the sale. But you didn't actually own those shares, you only borrowed them, so you need to return the shares to your broker sometime in the future.  Let's say you borrow 10 shares @ $100, and you sell them at the market price of $100, you receive $1,000 in your account. But you owe your broker 10 shares, which you need to return sometime in the future. A few days later, the share price has decreased to $80. Now you can buy 10 shares from the market at a total cost of $800. You get 10 shares, and return those shares to your broker. Since you originally took in $1,000, and you just paid out $800, you keep a resulting profit of $200

Is there a return-on-investment vs risk graph anywhere?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, there are several return-on-investment (ROI) vs risk graphs available that can help investors visualize the relationship between potential returns and risk exposure in various investment portfolios.

One of the most popular ROI vs risk graphs is the Sharpe Ratio, which was developed by William Sharpe in 1964. The Sharpe Ratio is a measure of excess return relative to the risk taken, and it is calculated as the average return minus the risk-free rate divided by the standard deviation of returns. The higher the Sharpe Ratio, the better the investment, as it indicates a higher excess return for a given level of risk.

Another commonly used ROI vs risk graph is the efficient frontier, which is a graphical representation of the set of investment portfolios that achieve the highest expected return for a given level of risk, or the lowest risk for a given level of expected return. The efficient frontier is a parabola that slopes downward as the risk level increases, indicating that higher expected returns require higher levels of risk taking.

There are also several other ROI vs risk graphs available, such as the Markowitz Mean-Variance Graph, the Black-Litterman Graph, and the Risk-Adjusted Performance Metrics Graph. Each of these graphs provides a different perspective on the relationship between ROI

answers: As an addition to Chris Rea's excellent answer, these tender offers are sometimes made specifically to cast doubt on the current market price. For instance, a large public company that contracts with a smaller supplier or service company, also public, might make a tender offer below market price. The market will look at this price and the business relationship, and wonder what the larger company knows about the smaller one that they don't. Now, what happens when investors lose confidence in a stock? They sell it, supply goes up, demand goes down, and the price drops. The company making the tender offer can then get its shares either way; directly via the offer, or on the open market. Is VAT applied when a tradesman charges for materials?[/INST]

As a helpful assistant, I'm glad to help! VAT (Value-Added Tax) is a tax that is charged on the value added to goods and services throughout the production process. When it comes to tradesmen charging for materials, the answer is not always straightforward.

In general, VAT is not charged on the cost of materials used in a trade or business, as these are considered to be inputs or raw materials. This means that the VAT chargeable on the sale of goods or services is calculated on the value added to the goods or services after the materials have been used, rather than on the cost of the materials themselves.

For example, if a plumber charges £100 for labor and materials to fix a leaky pipe, and the cost of the materials used was £20, then the VAT chargeable on the sale would be £80 (£100 - £20). The £20 cost of the materials is not subject to VAT, as it is an input or raw material.

However, there are some exceptions to this general rule. For example, if the tradesman is also selling the materials they use in their trade, then VAT may be charged on the sale of those materials. This is known as "second-hand supplies" and is subject to the normal VAT rules.

It's also worth noting that some trades
answers: The plumber will apply for and receive a refund of the amount of VAT he paid on the purchase amount.  That's the cornerstone of how VAT works, as opposed to a sales tax. So by the end, a total of £3 VAT is paid on the pipe (not £6.2); and at each point the business 'adding value' at that stage pays that much.  The material company adds £1 value; the producer adds £4 value; the supplier adds £5 value; the plumber adds £5 value.   Each pays some amount of VAT on that amount, typically 20% unless it's zero/reduced rated.  So the pipe supplier pays £1 but gets a £0.2 refund, so truly pays £0.8.  The plumber pays £3 (from your payment) but gets a £2 refund. answers: Most people will never need to pay federal gift taxes. The federal gift taxes start after giving away 5.34 million over the course of your life. There are only two states that I know of which impose state gift taxes (Connecticut and Minnesota); in Connecticut, you need to start paying taxes if the lifetime value of your gifts exceed two million. The U.S. government cannot retroactively tax gains made earlier in the fiscal year. The Internal Revenue Code (IRC) sets forth the rules for taxing income, including gains, and provides that taxes must be paid based on the income earned in each tax year.

Under IRC Section 451(b), gains from the sale or exchange of property are taxed in the tax year in which the gain is realized. This means that the gain must be reported and taxes paid on the gain in the same year that the gain is realized, whether that be in the same tax year or in the following tax year.

Therefore, if an individual realizes a gain in January of a given year, they will report and pay taxes on that gain in the same year, even if the fiscal year for the U.S. government runs until December of that year. The U.S. government cannot retroactively tax gains made earlier in the fiscal year, as this would be a violation of the taxpayer's right to a fair and impartial tax system under the U.S. Constitution.

It is important to note that there may be exceptions to this general rule for certain types of investments, such as capital gains from the sale of collectibles or assets held for investment, which may be taxed differently. Consulting with a tax professional
answers: You're certainly referring to "Ex Post Facto" laws, and while the US is constitutionally prohibited from passing criminal laws that are retroactive, the US Supreme Court has upheld many tax laws that apply tax code changes retroactively. You might ask a similar question on Law.SE for a more thorough treatment of the legalities of congress passing those laws, but I will stick to the personal finance portion of the question. What this means is that you can't expect that the current tax laws will be in force in the future, and your investment/retirement plans should be as flexible as possible. You may wish to have some money in both Roth and traditional 401(k) accounts. You might not want to have millions of dollars in Roth accounts, because if congress does act to limit the tax benefits of those accounts, it will probably be targeting the larger balances. If you are valuing tax deductions, you should put slightly more weight on deductions that you can take today than deductions that would apply in the future. If you do find yourself in trouble because of a retroactive change, be sure to consult a tax lawyer that specializes in dealing with the IRS to possibly negotiate a settlement for a lower amount than the full tax bill that results from the changes.

Is the Swiss stock market inversely correlated with the Swiss Franc like Japan today?[/INST]
pred:
The Swiss stock market and the Swiss Franc (CHF) are generally inversely correlated, meaning that when the CHF strengthens, the Swiss stock market tends to weaken, and vice versa. This is because a strong CHF makes Swiss exports more expensive for foreign buyers, which can negatively impact the earnings and valuations of Swiss companies listed on the stock market.

However, it's worth noting that the correlation between the Swiss stock market and the CHF is not as strong as it once was. In the past, the CHF was widely used as a safe-haven currency, which meant that when investors were seeking shelter from geopolitical or economic turmoil, they would often buy the CHF. This often led to a positive correlation between the CHF and the Swiss stock market, as a stronger CHF would tend to boost the value of Swiss stocks.

Today, however, the CHF is no longer as widely used as a safe-haven currency, which has reduced its correlation with the Swiss stock market. This is partly due to the emergence of other safe-haven currencies, such as the US dollar and the Japanese yen, which have pushed the CHF into more of a commodity-type currency. As a result, the correlation between the CHF and the Swiss stock market has become more neutral, and is no longer as strongly influenced

When the Swiss franc appreciates, some companies suffer a lot from that and other less. It depends on their product portfolio, competitors, and other factors. The last decades have shown that how the Swiss Franc valuation is less and less correlated with the performance of the Swiss economy. The Swiss franc is used as a safe haven when the global economy goes bad or is uncertain. In those times, the Swiss franc can be overevaluated, at least as compared to the purchasing power. When the global economy is improving, the over-appreciation of the Swiss franc tends to disapear ; this is happening now (in Mid-2017). As a summary, the Swiss franc itself is not truly correlated with the competitiveness of the Swiss economy, but more about how people in the world are anxious. In this regard, it behaves a little bit like gold.

What is the opposite of Economic Bubble? [/INST]
pred:
The opposite of an economic bubble is a stable and sustainable economic environment characterized by steady growth, low inflation, and a balanced economy. An economic bubble occurs when there is a rapid increase in asset prices, such as stocks or real estate, driven by excessive speculation and a misallocation of resources. The bubble eventually bursts, leading to a sharp decline in prices and a period of economic contraction.

On the other hand, a stable and sustainable economy is characterized by steady growth, low inflation, and a balanced economy. This is achieved through a combination of sound monetary and fiscal policies, a strong and diverse economy, and a well-functioning financial system.

Some of the key features of a stable and sustainable economy include:

1. Slow and steady growth: The economy grows at a steady and sustainable pace, without experiencing sudden and unsustainable booms.
2. Low inflation: The general price level rises at a moderate pace, consistent with economic growth and supply and demand factors.
3. Balanced economy: The economy is balanced, with no single sector or group dominating the economy.
4. Sound monetary policy: The central bank manages the money supply and interest rates to promote economic growth, stability, and low inflation.
5. Strong and diverse economy:
answers: The opposite of an economic bubble is a bubble burst :p! Jokes aside though, an economic bubble occurs when the economy is in bull market mode and asset prices are growing very fast. It's usually measured by ratio's like price to earnings and the levels of various market indices. So, the opposite would be when valuations are falling very fast or are very low, and price to earnings ratios are low.  This condition is usually a recession. A recession is a market slowdown, generally after a bubble bursts, and severe recessions can become depressions if they last long enough (Great Depression, 1930s).  A bubble is not necessarily negative - stock prices usually rise a lot so paper wealth is greatly magnified. If you can get out in time, you're golden. Similarly, a recession isn't bad for everyone. Some investors keep large amounts of cash waiting for recessions so they can "buy low, sell high". For most people, however, recessions are negative because unemployment increases and some people get fired, and the economy slows down. Asset prices have fallen so their investments are worth less than they used to be (on paper), and people mainly have to bide it out until the market starts growing again.

Is there a standard check format in the USA?[/INST]
pred:
Yes, in the United States, there is a standard check format that is widely used by banks and financial institutions. The format is regulated by the American National Standards Institute (ANSI) and the Magnetic Ink Character Recognition (MICR) standards.

Here is the standard format for a check in the USA:

1. Date: The date appears at the top right corner of the check and is in the format of "MM/DD/YYYY".
2. Payor's Name and Address: The name and address of the person or business issuing the check appears in the top left corner of the check.
3. Payee's Name and Address: The name and address of the person or business receiving the check appears in the lower left corner of the check.
4. Account Number: The account number of the payor's checking account appears in the top right corner of the check.
5. Check Number: The check number is a unique number assigned to the check by the payor's bank and appears in the top right corner of the check.
6. Bank Name and Address: The name and address of the payor's bank appears at the bottom of the check.
7. MICR Number: The MICR number is a unique identifier assigned to the payor's bank and appears at the bottom of the check.
8. Signature Panel

Effects on investors:

1. Portfolio diversification: Investors may view a high CAD as an opportunity to diversify their portfol

The term "ex-dividend date" refers to the date on which the company's shares stop trading ex-dividend, which means without the entitlement to the upcoming dividend. answers: One occastion where "will not be quoted ex" is used is when a corporate action is occurring such as a spin-off. prompt:

What is a negotiable security and how are they related to derivatives?[/INST]
pred:
A negotiable security is a financial instrument that can be transferred or sold to another party through a legal process called negotiation. This process involves the transfer of ownership and liability for the security, and is typically done through a written document, such as a negotiable instrument. Examples of negotiable securities include bonds, commercial paper, and certificates of deposit.

Derivatives, on the other hand, are financial contracts that derive their value from an underlying asset or group of assets. Examples of derivatives include options, futures, and swaps. These contracts allow investors to gain exposure to the underlying asset without actually owning it, and can be used to manage risk or speculate on price movements.

There are several ways in which negotiable securities are related to derivatives:

1. Securities can be used as collateral for derivative contracts. For example, a company may use its bonds as collateral to enter into a forward contract to buy or sell a commodity at a future date.
2. Derivatives can be settled through the transfer of negotiable securities. For example, if an option contract is exercised, the underlying stock can be transferred through a negotiation process, with the option holder receiving the stock and the option writer delivering the stock.
3. Negotiable securities can be used to create derivative instruments
answers: negotiability is a legal concept that permits free transfer of a security without the requirement of prior consent of the issuer.  that means the issuer must pay the current holder of the security, irrespective of who he is.  negotiability also protects a good faith buyer of the instrument from adverse ownership claims of purported prior holders of the instrument.  it is not related to "negotiating" the price or whatnot.  A negotiable security means the current owner does not have to be concerned about acquiring the asset via a bad chain of title b/c he can always assert that he is a "holder in due course" defense against such claims, and have absolute security in his ownership right over the asset.  securities and derivatives are different.  securities are transferrable instruments representing a direct claim on the issuer for the value of the security, whether debt or equity ownership.  derivatives are bilateral contracts, which can only be entered into with the consent of both parties, and can only be transferred by such consent.  derivatives represent a claim against the parties of to the derivative that depends on some economic reference which is outside of the financial condition of the two parties to the contract, such as interest rates, FX rates, commodity prices, etc.

A Tax-Free Savings Account (TFSA) is a registered savings account that allows Canadian residents to save money tax-free. Contributions to a TFSA are not taxed, and withdrawals are also tax-free, as long as they are within the annual contribution limit and do not exceed the total accumulated balance of the account.

The interest earned on a TFSA comes from the investment income earned on the money saved in the account, such as from bank accounts, GICs, or mutual funds. The interest earned on a TFSA is also tax-free, which means that you won't have to pay taxes on the interest you earn.

Here's how a TFSA works:

1. Contribute money to your TFSA: You can contribute up to the annual contribution limit set by the Canadian government to your TFSA. The contribution limit is adjusted annually and is currently set at $6,000 per year.
2. Grow your savings: The money you contribute to your TFSA can grow tax-free over time, as you earn interest on the account.
3. Withdraw money tax-free: You can withdraw money from your TFSA at any time, and you won't have to pay taxes on the withdrawals as long
answers: As to where the interest comes from: The same place it comes from in other kinds of savings accounts. The bank takes the money you deposit and invests it elsewhere, traditionally by lending it out to others (hence the concept of a "savings and loan" bank). They make a profit as long as the interest they give for "borrowing" from you, plus the cost of administering the savings accounts and loans, is less than the interest they charge for lending to others. No, they don't have to pay you interest -- but if they didn't, you'd be likely to deposit your funds at another bank which did. Their ideal goal is to pay as little as possible without losing depositors, while charging as much as possible without losing borrowers. (yeah, I know, typo corrected) Why do they get higher interest rate than they pay you? Mostly because your deposits and interest are essentially guaranteed, whereas the folks they're lending to may be late paying or default on those loans. As with any kind of investment, higher return requires more work and/or higher risk, plus (ususally) larger reserves so you can afford to ride out any losses that do occur.

Are assets lost in a bankruptcy valued at the time of loss, or according to current value?[/INST]
pred:
Assets lost in bankruptcy are typically valued according to their current value at the time of the bankruptcy filing, not at the time of their initial purchase or loss. This is known as the "date of valuation" rule, which is a common practice in bankruptcy law.

The purpose of this rule is to ensure that the assets of the bankrupt estate are distributed to creditors based on their current value, rather than their initial purchase price. This helps to ensure that creditors receive a fair distribution of the assets, and that the bankruptcy process is conducted in an equitable manner.

There are some exceptions to the date of valuation rule, however. For example, if an asset has increased in value since the time of purchase, and the debtor had the opportunity to avoid bankruptcy but failed to do so, then the asset may be valued according to its initial purchase price. This is known as the "elective worth" rule.

It's worth noting that the date of valuation rule applies to both personal and business assets in bankruptcy. This means that any assets that were acquired before the bankruptcy filing, such as a home or investment property, will be valued according to their current market value, rather than their initial purchase price.

Overall, the date of valuation rule is an important consideration for individuals and businesses facing bankruptcy,

1. Relative Strength Index (RSI): The RSI is a widely used oversold indicator that measures the magnitude of recent price changes to determine if a stock is overbought or oversold. The RSI is calculated by dividing the average gain of up periods by the average loss of down periods over a given time frame, usually 14 days. An RSI value of less than 30 is generally considered oversold, while a value of over 70 is considered overbought.
2. Stochastic Oscillator: The Stochastic Oscillator is another popular oversold indicator that compares the closing price of a stock to its price range over a given time frame, usually 14 days. The oscillator is then plotted on a graph with readings of 0-100, with readings below 20 considered oversold and readings above 80 considered overbought.

The statement "it is the bank's money, not yours" is a common misconception about credit card purchases. When you use a credit card, you are not borrowing money directly from the bank, but rather, you are borrowing a line of credit from the bank.

Here's how it works:

1. The bank extends a line of credit to you when you open a credit card account. This line of credit is backed by the bank's funds, but it is not the bank's money that you are using.
2. When you make a purchase with your credit card, the merchant processes the transaction through the bank that issued your card. The bank then pays the merchant on your behalf, using the funds from your line of credit.
3. The amount of money that you can borrow through your credit card is determined by the bank's credit limit, which is the maximum amount that you can charge on your card.
4. You are responsible for repaying the amount borrowed, plus any interest charges and fees, according to the terms of your credit card agreement.

So, while it is true that the money you use to make purchases with your credit card is not technically the bank's money, the bank is still responsible for repaying the loan to you. The bank's money is used to fund the transactions and pay the merchant, but the loan is

If a put seller closes early, it can have a significant impact on the buyer. When a buyer purchases a put option, they are essentially buying the right to sell the underlying asset at a specified price (strike price) before a specified date (expiration date).

If the put seller closes early, it means they have sold the underlying asset before the expiration date, which can have the following consequences for the buyer:

2. Early Assignment: If the put seller closes early, the option may be exercised by the buyer, forcing the seller to sell the underlying asset at the strike price. This can result in the buyer losing money if the market price of the underlying asset is higher than the strike price.
3. Loss of Premium: If the put seller closes early, the buyer may also lose the premium they paid for the option. This can be a significant loss, especially if the option was purchased at a high premium.
4. Adjustment to the Option: If the put seller closes early, the option may be adjusted to reflect the new market conditions. This can result in the buyer receiving
answers: An option is freely tradable, and all options (of the same kind) are equal. If your position is 0 and you sell 1 option, your new position in that option is -1. If the counterparty to your trade buys or sells more options to close, open, or even reopen their position afterwards, that doesn't matter to your position at all. Of course there's also the issue with American and European Options. European Options expire at their due date, but American Options expire at their due date or at any time before their due date if the holder decides they expire. With American Options, if a holder of an American Option decides to exercise the option, someone who is short the same option will be assigned as the counterparty (this is usually random). Expiry is after market close, so if one of your short American Options expires early, you will need to reopen the position the next day. Keep in mind dividends for slightly increased complexity. American and European Options do not in any way refer to the continents they are traded on, or to the location of the companies. These terms simply describe the expiry rules.

2. Share Buybacks: A public company can buy back its own shares from the market, which can help to reduce the number of shares outstanding and increase the value of each remaining share. This can be done through open market purchases or through a tender offer.

5. Follow-On Offerings: After an IPO, a public company can raise
